name: How is inheritance expressed?
subject: Biology
description: This topic explores how genetic information stored in DNA is expressed as functional proteins, and how gene expression is regulated in cells.

subtopics.name: Nucleic Acids
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers the structure and function of DNA and RNA as information molecules. You will learn how nucleotides are assembled into nucleic acid polymers and how the structural differences between DNA and RNA relate to their distinct roles in the cell.
subtopics.why: Understanding nucleic acids is foundational to all of molecular biology. These molecules carry the instructions for building proteins, and their structure directly determines how genetic information is stored, copied, and transferred within cells.

items.title: I can explain the roles of DNA and RNA as information molecules
items.what: DNA is the master copy of genetic instructions stored in the nucleus, while RNA is a transient copy used to transfer these instructions to the cytoplasm for protein synthesis.
items.why: This distinction explains why genetic information is preserved reliably in DNA while being actively used through RNA intermediates.
items.example: When a cell needs to make insulin, the DNA sequence for insulin stays safely in the nucleus while an RNA copy travels to the ribosome where the protein is actually made.

items.title: I can describe the structure of a nucleotide
items.what: A nucleotide consists of three components: a central 5-carbon pentose sugar, a phosphate group attached to the 5'-carbon, and a nitrogenous base attached to the 1'-carbon.
items.why: Knowing how nucleotides are structured helps you understand how they link together and why DNA and RNA have specific properties.
items.example: In a nucleotide diagram, the sugar is drawn as a pentagon with carbons numbered 1' to 5'. The phosphate attaches at the 5' position (left side) and the base at the 1' position (right side).

items.title: I can explain how nucleotides join to form nucleic acid polymers
items.what: Nucleotides connect via condensation reactions that form phosphodiester bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 3'-carbon of the next, creating a sugar-phosphate backbone.
items.why: This bonding pattern creates the directionality of DNA and RNA strands (5' to 3'), which is essential for understanding replication and transcription.
items.example: When two nucleotides join, a water molecule is released as the phosphate of one nucleotide bonds to the 3'-carbon of another, forming a chain like: sugar-phosphate-sugar-phosphate.

items.title: I can identify and classify the four nitrogenous bases in DNA and RNA
items.what: The purines (adenine and guanine) have a double-ring structure, while the pyrimidines (cytosine and thymine in DNA, or uracil in RNA) have a single-ring structure.
items.why: The size difference between purines and pyrimidines is why base pairing always involves one of each, maintaining a consistent width of the DNA double helix.
items.example: Adenine (A) and guanine (G) are purines with two rings. Cytosine (C), thymine (T), and uracil (U) are pyrimidines with one ring. Remember: 'Pure As Gold' for purines A and G.

items.title: I can compare the structural differences between DNA and RNA
items.what: DNA is double-stranded with deoxyribose sugar and thymine, while RNA is single-stranded with ribose sugar and uracil instead of thymine.
items.why: These structural differences reflect their functions: DNA's double strand protects genetic information, while RNA's single strand allows it to fold into functional shapes and be readily degraded after use.
items.example: Deoxyribose lacks one oxygen atom compared to ribose (hence 'deoxy'). This makes DNA more chemically stable than RNA, which is appropriate for long-term information storage.

items.title: I can describe the structure of DNA including base pairing, antiparallel strands, and double helix
items.what: DNA consists of two strands held by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases (A=T with 2 bonds, G‚â°C with 3 bonds). The strands run antiparallel (one 5'‚Üí3', the other 3'‚Üí5') and twist into a double helix.
items.why: Complementary base pairing enables accurate DNA replication, while the double helix structure provides stability and compact storage of genetic information.
items.example: If one DNA strand reads 5'-ATGCCA-3', the complementary strand runs 3'-TACGGT-5'. The G-C pairs are stronger (3 hydrogen bonds) than A-T pairs (2 bonds), so GC-rich regions are harder to separate.

items.title: I can describe the three main forms of RNA and their functions
items.what: Messenger RNA (mRNA) carries a copy of the genetic code from DNA. Transfer RNA (tRNA) delivers amino acids to the ribosome. Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) forms the catalytic core of ribosomes.
items.why: These three RNA types work together during translation: mRNA provides the instructions, tRNA brings the building blocks, and rRNA catalyses the assembly of proteins.
items.example: Think of protein synthesis like a factory: mRNA is the blueprint, tRNA are the delivery trucks bringing amino acid parts, and rRNA is the machinery that assembles the final product.

subtopics.name: Proteins
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers the structure of amino acids, how they form polypeptide chains, and how these chains fold into functional proteins with four levels of structure. You will also learn about protein diversity and functions.
subtopics.why: Proteins carry out almost all cellular functions, from catalysing reactions to providing structure. Understanding how protein structure determines function is central to understanding how genes influence traits.

items.title: I can describe the structure of an amino acid
items.what: An amino acid has a central carbon bonded to four groups: an amine group (NH‚ÇÇ), a carboxylic acid group (COOH), a hydrogen atom, and a variable R group (side chain).
items.why: The R group determines each amino acid's unique properties, which in turn determines how a protein will fold and function.
items.example: Glycine has the simplest R group (just a hydrogen), while phenylalanine has a large aromatic ring. These different R groups cause proteins to fold differently.

items.title: I can explain how the 20 universal amino acids differ in their side chain properties
items.what: The 20 amino acids have side chains with different chemical properties: some are hydrophobic (water-fearing), some hydrophilic (water-loving), some are charged, and some are polar.
items.why: These properties determine how amino acids interact with each other and their environment, driving protein folding and determining which parts of a protein face outward versus inward.
items.example: Membrane proteins have hydrophobic amino acids on their exterior (facing the fatty membrane) and hydrophilic amino acids lining any internal channels (allowing ions to pass through).

items.title: I can explain how polypeptides form via condensation reactions
items.what: Peptide bonds form between the amine group of one amino acid and the carboxylic acid group of another through a condensation reaction that releases water.
items.why: Understanding peptide bond formation helps you understand how proteins are built during translation and how they can be broken down by hydrolysis.
items.example: When alanine and glycine join, the -OH from alanine's COOH and the -H from glycine's NH‚ÇÇ combine to release H‚ÇÇO, leaving a peptide bond (-CO-NH-) connecting the two amino acids.

items.title: I can describe the four levels of protein structure and the bonds responsible for each
items.what: Primary structure is the amino acid sequence (peptide bonds). Secondary structure forms Œ±-helices and Œ≤-sheets (hydrogen bonds between backbone atoms). Tertiary structure is the 3D shape (R group interactions). Quaternary structure involves multiple polypeptides or prosthetic groups.
items.why: Each level builds on the previous one, and disrupting any level can cause the protein to lose function. This hierarchy explains how a linear sequence becomes a functional 3D molecule.
items.example: Haemoglobin has quaternary structure: four polypeptide chains (two Œ±, two Œ≤) plus four haeme groups. Each chain has its own tertiary structure with Œ±-helices (secondary) built from a specific amino acid sequence (primary).

items.title: I can explain denaturation and its causes
items.what: Denaturation is a structural change in a protein that causes loss of biological function. It is typically caused by temperature changes (disrupting hydrogen bonds) or pH changes (altering protein charge).
items.why: Denaturation explains why enzymes have optimal temperature and pH ranges, and why fever or acidosis can disrupt normal body function.
items.example: Cooking an egg denatures the albumin protein: heat breaks hydrogen bonds, causing the protein to unfold and aggregate, turning the egg white from clear and runny to white and solid. This change is irreversible.

items.title: I can describe the diverse functions of proteins with examples
items.what: Proteins serve many functions: structural (collagen in skin), hormonal (insulin regulating blood sugar), immune (antibodies), transport (haemoglobin carrying oxygen), enzymatic (catalase breaking down hydrogen peroxide), and movement (actin and myosin in muscles).
items.why: This diversity shows how the same basic building blocks (amino acids) can create molecules with vastly different properties and roles, all determined by their sequence and structure.
items.example: Collagen is a fibrous protein with a rope-like structure providing tensile strength to tendons. Haemoglobin is a globular protein with a compact shape containing iron-binding sites for oxygen transport. Same building blocks, completely different functions.

items.title: I can explain the concept of a proteome and how it differs from the genome
items.what: The proteome is all proteins expressed in a cell, tissue, or organism at a given time. It is larger and more variable than the genome due to alternative splicing and post-translational modifications.
items.why: The proteome explains how different cell types with identical DNA can have different structures and functions‚Äîthey express different subsets of proteins.
items.example: A human has about 20,000 genes but over 100,000 different proteins. One gene can produce multiple protein variants through alternative splicing (removing different exons) and modifications like adding sugar groups (glycosylation).

subtopics.name: Gene Expression
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers how genetic information flows from DNA to RNA to protein through transcription and translation. You will learn about gene structure, RNA processing, the genetic code, and protein trafficking.
subtopics.why: Gene expression is the process by which genetic information becomes functional molecules. Understanding this process explains how mutations can cause disease and how cells control their activities.

items.title: I can describe the central dogma of molecular biology
items.what: The central dogma states that genetic information flows from DNA to RNA (transcription) to protein (translation). Some viruses can reverse this using reverse transcriptase to convert RNA to DNA.
items.why: This concept provides the framework for understanding how genes are expressed and why DNA is considered the fundamental unit of heredity.
items.example: HIV is a retrovirus that uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA genome into DNA, which then integrates into the host cell's genome. This is an exception to the usual one-way flow of information.

items.title: I can describe the structure of a gene including promoter, coding sequence, and terminator
items.what: A gene consists of a promoter (where RNA polymerase binds to start transcription), a coding sequence (the part that is transcribed), and a terminator (where transcription stops).
items.why: Understanding gene structure explains how transcription is controlled and why mutations in different regions have different effects.
items.example: A mutation in the promoter might prevent RNA polymerase from binding, so the gene is never transcribed. A mutation in the coding sequence might change the resulting protein. A mutation in the terminator might produce an abnormally long transcript.

items.title: I can describe the process of transcription
items.what: During transcription, RNA polymerase binds to the promoter, separates the DNA strands, synthesises a complementary RNA strand by adding nucleotides in the 5' to 3' direction, and detaches at the terminator.
items.why: Transcription is the first step in gene expression and creates RNA copies that can leave the nucleus while the DNA master copy stays protected.
items.example: If the DNA template strand reads 3'-TACGGA-5', RNA polymerase will synthesise an mRNA strand reading 5'-AUGCCU-3' (note: uracil replaces thymine in RNA).

items.title: I can describe RNA processing in eukaryotes
items.what: Eukaryotic RNA processing includes capping (adding a methyl group to the 5' end), polyadenylation (adding a poly-A tail to the 3' end), and splicing (removing introns and joining exons).
items.why: These modifications protect the mRNA from degradation, help it exit the nucleus, and ensure only the coding regions are translated.
items.example: A freshly transcribed mRNA might be 10,000 nucleotides long. After splicing removes the introns, the mature mRNA might be only 2,000 nucleotides. The cap and poly-A tail are then added before export to the cytoplasm.

items.title: I can explain alternative splicing and its significance
items.what: Alternative splicing is the selective removal of different exons from the same pre-mRNA, resulting in different mature mRNAs and therefore different protein variants from a single gene.
items.why: Alternative splicing explains how organisms can produce more proteins than they have genes, increasing proteomic diversity without increasing genome size.
items.example: The gene for tropomyosin can be spliced differently in muscle cells versus brain cells. The resulting proteins have different properties suited to their tissue-specific functions.

items.title: I can describe the process of translation
items.what: During translation, ribosomes read mRNA codons starting at AUG. tRNA molecules with complementary anticodons bring specific amino acids. Peptide bonds form between amino acids until a stop codon is reached.
items.why: Translation is where the genetic code is actually decoded into protein, making it the key step where genetic information becomes functional molecules.
items.example: The mRNA sequence AUG-GCA-UAA would be translated as: start codon (AUG, methionine) - GCA (alanine) - stop codon (UAA). The resulting dipeptide would be Met-Ala.

items.title: I can explain the features of the genetic code
items.what: The genetic code is a triplet code (three bases per codon), universal (same in almost all organisms), and degenerate (multiple codons can code for the same amino acid). There are 64 codons, including one start codon (AUG) and three stop codons.
items.why: The universality of the genetic code allows genes to be transferred between species (e.g., human insulin gene in bacteria). Degeneracy provides some protection against mutations.
items.example: The amino acid leucine is encoded by six different codons (UUA, UUG, CUU, CUC, CUA, CUG). This means a mutation in the third position of a leucine codon often still produces leucine‚Äîa silent mutation.

items.title: I can explain how protein destination is determined and describe the secretory pathway
items.what: Proteins made on free ribosomes stay in the cytosol. Proteins made on rough ER ribosomes enter the secretory pathway: they are packaged in vesicles, modified in the Golgi apparatus, and exported via exocytosis.
items.why: This explains how cells direct proteins to the correct locations‚Äîwhether they stay inside the cell or are secreted to function elsewhere.
items.example: Insulin is a secreted hormone. It is synthesised at the rough ER, transported to the Golgi for processing (removing part of the chain), stored in vesicles, and released when blood glucose rises.

subtopics.name: Gene Regulation
subtopics.what: This subtopic covers how cells control which genes are expressed and when. You will learn about structural and regulatory genes, transcription factors, and the trp operon as a model for understanding gene regulation.
subtopics.why: Gene regulation explains how cells with identical DNA can have different functions, and how organisms respond to changing conditions by turning genes on or off.

items.title: I can distinguish between structural genes and regulatory genes
items.what: Structural genes encode proteins that contribute to the form or function of the cell. Regulatory genes encode transcription factors that control the expression of other genes.
items.why: This distinction shows that genes can have different roles‚Äîsome make the 'workers' while others act as 'managers' controlling when workers are produced.
items.example: In the trp operon, the structural genes encode enzymes that synthesise tryptophan. The regulatory gene (trpR) encodes the trp repressor protein that controls whether those enzymes are made.

items.title: I can explain how transcription factors regulate gene expression
items.what: Transcription factors are proteins that control transcription by interacting with RNA polymerase. Repressors prevent transcription by blocking RNA polymerase. Activators promote transcription by enhancing RNA polymerase binding.
items.why: Transcription factors allow precise control of gene expression in response to cellular conditions, enabling cells to adapt to their environment.
items.example: The lac repressor blocks transcription of genes for lactose digestion when lactose is absent. When lactose is present, it binds to the repressor and inactivates it, allowing transcription to proceed.

items.title: I can describe the function of the operator region in prokaryotes
items.what: The operator is a DNA sequence adjacent to the promoter where transcription factors (particularly repressors) bind to control gene expression in prokaryotes.
items.why: The operator provides a specific control point for gene regulation, allowing repressors to physically block RNA polymerase from transcribing the gene.
items.example: In the trp operon, the operator is located between the promoter and the structural genes. When the trp repressor binds to the operator, RNA polymerase cannot move past it to transcribe the genes.

items.title: I can describe the structure and function of the trp operon
items.what: The trp operon is a cluster of genes in bacteria that encode enzymes for tryptophan synthesis. These genes share a single promoter and are regulated together by the trp repressor binding to the operator.
items.why: The trp operon is a classic example of how bacteria efficiently regulate related genes as a unit, saving energy by only making tryptophan synthesis enzymes when needed.
items.example: E. coli has five structural genes in the trp operon (trpE, trpD, trpC, trpB, trpA) that work together to synthesise tryptophan. Having them in an operon means they are all switched on or off together.

items.title: I can explain how tryptophan levels regulate the trp operon
items.what: When tryptophan is abundant, it binds to the trp repressor, activating it. The active repressor binds to the operator and blocks transcription. When tryptophan is scarce, the repressor is inactive and transcription proceeds.
items.why: This is an example of negative feedback regulation‚Äîthe product of the pathway (tryptophan) controls its own production, preventing wasteful overproduction.
items.example: If a bacterium is in a tryptophan-rich environment, it would be wasteful to make tryptophan synthesis enzymes. High tryptophan activates the repressor, blocking the operon. When tryptophan runs low, the repressor releases from the operator and enzyme production resumes.
